and for the same reason Bise reflecting blew most copiously, shall 
appeare blew by the excess of those rays in its reflected light and the 
like of other bodies And that this is the intire and adequate cause of 
their colour is manifest because they haue noe power to change or alter 
the colours of any sort of rays incident a part but put on all colours 
indifferently wth wch they are inlightened 
These things being soe, it can be no longer disputed whether there be colours 
in the darke, nor whether they be the qualities of the objects wee see no nor 
perhaps whether light be a body For since colours are the qualities of 
light haveing its Rays for their intire & immediate Subject how can we 
thinke those Rays qualities also unless one quality may be the subject of 
and Susteyne another wch in effect is to call it Substance We should 
not know bodies for Substances were it not for their Sensible qualities 
and ye principall of those being now found due to something else we 
haue as good reason to beleive that to be a Substance also 
Besides who ever thought any quality to be heterogeneous aggregate 
such as light is discouered to be But to determine more absolutely what 
light is after wt manner refracted and by wt modes or actions it produceth 
in our minds the Phantasme of colours is not soe easy And I shall not 
mingle conjectures wth certaintyes 
Reviewing wt I haue written I see the discourse it selfe will leed[?] to
divers experim[en]ts sufficient for its examination And therefore I shall not 
trouble you further then to discribe one of those wch I haue alread insinuated 
In a darke roome make a whole in ye shute of a window whose diameter 
may conveniently be about a third part of an Inch to admitt a convenient 
quantity of the suns Light And there place a cleere & colourlesse prisme 
to refract the entring light towards the further part of ye roome wch as I 
said will thereby be defused into an oblong coloured Image then place a Lens 
of about three foot radious (suppose a broad object glass of a three foote 
Telescope) at the distance of about 4 or 5 foot from thence through wch 
all those colours may at once be transmited and made by its refraction to 
convene at a further distance of about 10 or 12 feet, If at that distance 
you intercept this light wth a sheet of white paper you shall se the colours 
converted into whitenes againe by being mingled but it is requisite that ye 
Prisme and Lens be placed steddy and that the paper on wch the colours are cast 
be moved to & fro by such motion you shall not onely find at what distance ye 
whitenesse is most perfect but alsoe see how the colours gradually convene and 
vanish into whitenesse and afterwards haueing crossed one another in that 
place where they compound whitenes are againe dissipated and severed and in 
an inverted order reteyne ye same colours which they had before they entred ye 
composition You may alsoe se that if any of the colours at the Lens be intercepted 
the whiteness will be changed into ye other colours And there fore that the composition 
of whiteness be perfect care must be taken that none of the colours fall besides ye 
Lens 
In the annexed designe of this experiment A B C expresseth the 
Prisme set endwise to sight close by the whole F of the window
